docs.lead_paragraph: A revolt among investors over a takeover bid involving two Canadian telephone companies is the latest sign that a long tradition of politeness toward corporate directors and managers north of the border is eroding. The Toronto Stock Exchange is due to decide Wednesday whether Manitoba Telecom Services of Winnipeg can proceed with a proposed bid of 1.7 billion Canadian dollars ($1.3 billion) for Allstream Inc., formerly AT&T Canada, without first seeking the approval of its own shareholders.

docs.lead_paragraph: The State Senate approved legislation yesterday overhauling medical malpractice laws, the subject of strikes and demonstrations last year by doctors across the state. The 22-to-15 vote followed party lines. The measure establishes a fund to help pay malpractice insurance premiums for doctors in high-risk specialties like obstetrics and neurosurgery. It does not cap damages awards, as Republicans had wanted, but gives judges more authority to limit them. The General Assembly, which has approved a similar bill, will now receive the Senate version. Laura Mansnerus (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: You report that according to a government report, the financial condition of Medicare has deteriorated because of exploding health costs and the new Medicare law (front page, March 24). It boggles my mind how middle-class Republicans -- people who will really need Medicare and Social Security -- believe that the government can reduce its income indefinitely through permanent tax cuts and simultaneously afford basic entitlement programs for an increasingly old and poor population.

docs.lead_paragraph: To Maryann Milani, there is something wrong with a legal system that she believes put her disabled son's financial future in the hands of Ronald A. Straci. Mr. Straci is a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in labor law and whose clients over the years have included some union leaders and locals that government investigators have linked to organized crime. (In 1990, he represented the brother of Anthony Salerno, the Genovese family crime boss known as ''Fat Tony.'') These days, Mr. Straci is better known as an owner of Rao's, the East Harlem restaurant that has been the embodiment of ''Sopranos'' chic since before the invention of cable television -- or broadcast television, for that matter.

headline.main: In the Hands of a Troubled System; A Woman Questions the Guardianship of Her Disabled Son

docs.abstract: Maryann Milani of Rockland County, NY, seeks to have Ronald A Straci removed as co-guardian with her of her 23-year-old son, Christopher, who has cerebral palsy and is severely mentally retarded and who received $1.75 million from settlement of malpractice lawsuit that his parents filed in Bronx against doctors who handled his birth; contends that Straci, labor lawyer and restaurateur in Manhattan, lacks expertise to ensure that award will see Christopher through life and has not visited him as often as law requires; says value of Christopher's investments has dropped by about $400,000; Justice Bertram Katch of Bronx, who oversaw Christopher's settlement, defends appointment of Straci as co-guardian; Straci defends his work; state's system of appointing guardians for those who cannot look out for themselves has long been plagued by allegations about influence of political patronage and favoritism; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Medicare Overseers Expect Costs to Soar in Coming Decades'' (front page, March 24): Medicare's financial condition is more a function of government priorities than rising health care costs. The United States is far wealthier than every other industrialized country. These other countries rein in costs and devote resources to providing health care coverage for all their citizens, not simply the elderly and people with disabilities.

docs.lead_paragraph: Study Financed by Insurers Calls for Federal Regulation Researchers at the University of Massachusetts are releasing a study today that advocates a strong federal role in insurance regulation, which has been the province of the states for more than 150 years. The study, financed by insurers and an industry trade group at a cost of $300,000, notes that state regulation is regarded as inefficient, costly and a drag on the competitiveness of insurers as they compete with banks and mutual fund companies for customers. [Page C2.] Prince Opens Online Music Store Prince's love-hate relationship with the mainstream music industry takes another turn today as he opens his online Musicology Download Store, turning his back on download services like Napster, Rhapsody and Apple's iTunes. The move comes a week after Prince appeared to be making peace with an industry he once compared to a form of slavery, announcing that he would team up with Columbia Records to release his new album. Prince's lawyer and business partner said the store was intended to increase membership in Prince's NPG Music Club. [C9.]
